Dear Mr. Derscheid:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Resident work experience.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4135
Section (3) Residents shall not be permitted to work for staff members’
Description personal gain and shall be protected from personal exploitation.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth are completing off campus work for staff.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 1 was interviewed via telephone on 4/29/2024.
Complainant 1 provided Complainant 2’s contact information
regarding additional concerns. Complainant 1 did not have any
further information.
Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on 4/29/2024.
Complainant 2 reported Staff 1 shot a deer and took Youth G to
help track the deer and pull skin off. Youth G did not want to pull
the skin off. Youth B has gone to Staff 1’s property to clear brush,
build a dock, and load wood for a staff’s uncle.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 1
reported youth go off facility grounds to complete work at different
locations. Youth have work detail hours where youth get an
allowance based on their level in the program. Staff 1 has taken
youth, no specific youth’s names were identified, to his property
where there is a lake. Youth have assisted in putting a dock in so
the youth can fish there. Youth have gone on a voluntary basis.
Staff 1 has bought youth dinner as a means of payment. Youth
assisted Staff 2 in cutting firewood for bonfires. Administrator 1
2

did not know anything about loading wood for furniture. Youth
assisted Staff 2’s uncle with cutting wood. Staff 2’s uncle was
previously a volunteer at the facility. Youth have assisted on a
voluntary basis in tracking deer. Administrator 2 is writing a policy
to submit to Division of Child Welfare Licensing that would allow
youth to bow hunt at the facility if the youth is interested. The
facility educates youth where food comes from, and youth have
enjoyed learning about hunting. Youth are never made to do
anything regarding working off campus, tracking or skinning deer.
Staff are aware they must ensure youth willingly participate in
these activities. The facility uses these as teachable moments.
The facility does not have a policy/procedure regarding youth
assisting in tracking/skinning deer.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Administrator 2
reported youth have assisted Staff 1 and Staff 2 in projects at their
properties which have included cutting firewood for the facility to
use to cook down maple syrup that the youth are making. Youth
G assisted in tracking a deer last hunting season. Youth G asked
multiple times to go track deer. Youth G enjoyed the experience.
Youth A was interviewed via teams on 5/13/2024. Youth A
reported he has gone to Staff 2’s property on two occasions to
complete work including moving and stacking logs and cleaning
up brush after Staff 2 had cut down trees. Youth A enjoyed doing
the work and volunteered to go. Staff 2 selects youth to go assist
him at his property based on the youth “doing the best” in the
house. Youth A was informed of the projects that would be worked
on both times before he went with Staff 2. Youth A received an
extra snack and drink as payment. Youth A went to Staff 1’s
property once, he did not complete any work as all the work had
been completed. Youth A has never assisted any staff in tracking
deer.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported youth do
work around the facility including chores in the house. Youth can
volunteer to work in the barn with the animals, but it is not
required. Staff 1 has property with a lake he has gone to and
moved logs and stacked wood to build a dock over the swamp to
the lake. The dock is to allow youth to be able to fish at Staff 1’s
property. Youth B has fished at Staff 1’s property and Staff 1
cleaned the fish for the youth to eat. Youth B reported he has
volunteered to do the work. Staff 1 has bought him two liters of
pop for working. Youth have to get all their points in school per the
3

behavior program in order to participate. Youth B has not done
any other work for staff.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C has
gone to Staff 1’s property to fish. Staff 1 has brought power tools
for the youth to use to complete projects such as a power saw and
drill to remove nails from wood for bonfires at Staff 1’s house with
the youth. Youth C has picked up sticks and leaves at Staff 1’s
house for bonfires. Youth C was paid for his work with a two liter
of pop and food including a cheese, sausage, cracker tray for all
the youth. Youth C voluntarily has picked up sticks, leaves, and
prepped wood for the bonfires at Staff 1’s house.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth D has
gone to Staff 1’s property to help build a dock to the lake and was
paid in soda. Youth D reported the youth are only able to fish at
the lake if there is a lifeguard there. Youth D volunteered to go
and help with building the dock, as youth are not forced to go.
Youth D has assisted Staff 2’s uncle cleaning out water holes for
deer and cutting fence to put around trees. Youth D was paid in a
drink and a snack. Youth D has not tracked deer at the facility and
was unaware of any youth tracking deer with staff.
Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth E has
gone to Staff 2’s property to cut wood for bonfires and helped
build a hunting blind for Staff 2, Staff 2’s uncle, and cousin to hunt
from. Youth E was paid in snacks. Payment depends on the work
that has been completed and provided the example of when he
splits wood with the wood splitting machine, he has received a big
bag of chips and two liter of pop. Youth E reported it is voluntary
work, he chooses to go. Youth E goes to Staff 2’s property usually
once a week. Youth E has gone to Staff 1’s property and helped
build a bridge through the swamp to the lake for the youth to be
able to fish. Youth E has been paid in snacks for doing this work.
Youth E enjoys being around Staff 1 and does not ask to be paid.
Staff 1 just gives him snacks. Staff 1 has bought him and other
youth McDonalds for helping. Youth E went to Staff 2’s uncles to
help track a deer. Once they located the deer, the deer was
brought back to the facility for the youth to be able to help and
learn how to clean the deer. Youth E helped skin the deer by
ripping the “silver skin” off. Youth E wanted to do this. The deer
meat was left at the facility for the youth who wanted to eat it.
4

Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/1/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth F
reported youth do chores at the facility including making their bed,
wash windows, and vacuum the house. No other work/chores are
required. Youth F went with Staff 2 and raked out water holes to
get the leaves out and was paid with McDonalds. Staff 2’s uncle
gave him zebra cakes. Youth F cut chicken wire to be put around
trees at Staff 2’s uncle’s house. Youth F reported youth are not
paid in money, they are paid in snacks and pop. Some staff have
put money in youth accounts for them to purchase items from the
store at the facility. Youth F went to Staff 2’s property and helped
get soil samples to be sent in to be tested and stacked logs for
Staff 2 to stand behind to turkey hunt. Youth F has gone to
Administrator 1’s house and helped pull nails out of old wood and
was paid by getting McDonalds. Youth F reported it was all
voluntary work. Youth F has never helped track deer at the facility.
Youth F has not done any work at Staff 1’s property, he has only
gone there to fish.
Youth G was attempted to be interviewed via telephone on
5/20/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth G is no
longer at the facility and has returned home to his father who
refused to allow an interview.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 5/1/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Staff 1
took youth from the facility to his property voluntarily to cut up
firewood to have bonfires and smores at his house. Staff 1 has
taken several youth on multiple occasions and was unable to
recall which youth he took when. Staff 1 has “paid” youth in
providing two liters of pop. Staff 1 talked about building a dock
through the swamp for the youth at the facility to use to fish
however that has not occurred. Staff 1 takes youth a couple times
a week to his property pending the weather to fish. Administrator
1 has approved for Staff 1 to take the youth to his property. Staff 1
reported youth have assisted him in clearing brush at his property
and gathering wood for bonfires. Staff 1 recalled Youth G assisting
with tracking a deer and Youth G “having the time of his life” and
enjoying the experience.
Staff 2 was interviewed via teams 0n 5/13/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported he has
taken youth from the facility to his mother’s property and his
uncle’s property on a voluntary basis to walk around and explore.
Staff 2 reported youth enjoy being able to go off campus and
explore in the woods. While at his mother’s property the youth
5

have moved branches off the trail if they are in the way. Staff 2
took youth to his mother’s property while he planted a food plot
however, he planted the food plot. Staff 2 denied youth have cut
wood at his mother or uncle’s property to be used for bonfires or
furniture. Youth have assisted at Staff 2’s uncle’s property in
cutting grape vines that were brought back to the facility and
planted in the green house. Youth have assisted with firewood at
the facility, on the facility grounds. Staff 1 has taken youth to his
property to fish and for bonfires. Staff 2 was unaware of any
specific job’s youth have completed at Staff 2’s property however
stated youth receive drinks and dinner/chips for helping. Staff 2
has taken youth twice to help track deer, once for him at his
mother’s property and once for Staff 1 on Staff 1’s property.
Youth wanted and volunteered to go look for the deer. Staff 2
gutted his deer while youth watched. Staff 2 has worked with
youth on the facilities property to build deer blinds that were taken
to Staff 1’s property. Youth did not go when the blinds were taken
to Staff 1’s property.
Documents Reviewed:
• Prohibition of Job-Related Exploitation Policy: On a minimal
and periodic scale, Pineview Homes offers employment
opportunities and basic employment related training to
residents and makes reasonable efforts to provide basic
training and mentorship involving carious jobs such as lawn
care maintenance, custodial work, or periodic community
generated job opportunities. Paid job opportunities are
completely voluntary. Pineview Homes prohibits the
exploitation of residents by ensuring that residents
volunteering for work detail projects is paid commiserate to
time and/or task outlined prior to them agreeing to take the
job; ensuring residents are paid promptly the agreed upon
payment, or that their financial count reflects the payment
at the next allowance account posting.
• Pineview Resident Handbook: Cleaning Duties:
Houseparent list various morning duties that include a job
for each youth, these duties are to be performed as
scheduled. Level System: includes level 1 through 5
indicating the biweekly allowance that is given to the youth
based on their level and indicates levels 3 through 5 may
go off grounds with staff.
• Staff 1 and Staff 2’s personnel file: Staff 1 and Staff 2 have
no discipline. Staff 1 and Staff 2 received facility policy
trainings on 1/16/2024.
6

Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as per interviews youth and
staff, youth have be permitted to work for staff’s personal gain.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical Assistance was offered for the facility to update policy
regarding youth volunteering or working cannot be for staff’s
personal gain. Youth should be aware of the work tasks that will
be completed in the community prior to going and be provided
with how they will be compensated for the work. It is
recommended the facility complete a work agreement form with
the youth prior to the job being conducted where it clearly outlines
the job tasks, compensation, and the youth sign agreeing to the
work task.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation A youth was grabbed under the arms in a hug type hold, lifted up,
and slammed on the bed. The staff pointed their finger at the
youth and told the youth if he did not stop, the youth would be sent
back to juvenile detention.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant 2 was interviewed via telephone on 4/29/2024.
Complainant 2 reported no additional information.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility in collaboration with MDHHS Worker.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were both unaware of a
recent situation regarding a youth and Staff 1. The facility has not
had any recent restraints.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth B reported he did not
see what happen in Youth C’s bedroom however heard it from his
bedroom and Youth C told him. Youth B reported Youth C “went
crazy” last week. Two staff were working in the house, Youth B
7

could not recall who, and the staff called Staff 1 to come assist.
Staff 1 arrived at the house and went into Youth C’s bedroom to
talk to him. Youth B reported Youth C told him Staff 1 told Youth
C to sit down and be good or Staff 1 would have to restrain him as
Youth C attempted to fight other youth in the house. Youth B did
not know which youth. Youth C told Staff 1 he was going to punch
him in the face and did. Staff 1 just sat there and did not respond
to Youth C punching him. Staff 1 picked Youth C up under his
armpits and set him in the chair. Staff 1 did not restraint Youth C.
Youth C nor Staff 1 had any injuries. Staff 1 was calm, and Youth
B did not have any concerns with Staff 1.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Youth C reported he was
upset and tried to fight other youth in the house. Staff 1 was
called to assist. When Staff 1 arrived, Youth C was in his
bedroom. Staff 1 stood in Youth C’s bedroom doorway to talk to
him. Youth C tried to leave his bedroom to go fight and Staff 1
“gently” took a hold of Youth C’s wrist and guided him to a chair in
the bedroom and told him to sit down. Youth C told Staff 1 he
would have to make him sit down but sat down willingly. Youth C
reported Staff 1 did not squeeze his wrist or hurt him in any way.
Staff 1 did not restrain him, lift him up in a hug type position, or
slam him on the bed. Staff 1 did point his finger at Youth C and
made a “mimic” sound as he was trying to use humor and
impersonate someone. Youth C has a good rapport with Staff 1.
Youth C told Staff 1 after the incident that a trigger of his is when
people point in his face. Staff 1 told Youth C he would not do it
again. Staff 1 never said if Youth C did not stop he would send
him back to juvenile detention. Youth C reported Staff 1 is his
favorite staff and he did not do anything wrong. No other staff or
youth witnessed the incident as all the youth were in their
bedrooms and the staff working, Youth C could not remember
who, were downstairs. Youth C feels safe at the facility and had
no concerns.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker. Staff 1 reported Youth C
was upset and throwing punches and items at youth in the house.
Staff 1 was called to assist. Staff 1 did not recall which staff were
working in the house. Staff 1 arrived at the house and Youth C
was in his bedroom. Staff 1 stood in Youth C’s doorway and Youth
C attempted to exit his bedroom. Staff 1 guided Youth C to the
chair in his bedroom by holding his wrist. Youth C sat down. Staff
1 talked to Youth C. Youth C began to cry and Staff 1 de-
escalated Youth C. Staff 1 reported he and Youth C were the only
8

ones in the bedroom. Staff 1 denied picking Youth C up,
slamming Youth C on the bed, pointing his finger in Youth C’s
face, and threatening to send Youth C back to detention. Staff 1
reported he did not restrain Youth C. Staff 1 did not recall pointing
his finger and making a “mimicking sound” or Youth C ever telling
him that finger pointing is a trigger for him.
Documents Reviewed:
• Behavioral Support and Management Policy: Safe Crisis
Management philosophy, training and practices shall be
utilized when engaging residents in behavior management
situations.
• There was no incident report for the incident as Youth A
was not restrained.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: Staff 1 has no discipline and
received child handling training on 9/19/2023 and
appropriate discipline training on 11/13/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Youth C and Staff 1 denied
Staff 1 grabbed Youth C under the arms in a hug type hold, lifted
Youth C up, and slammed him on the bed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
